lead_paragraph: A mural program called Public Art/Public Housing is being conducted in five New York City low-income housing projects with high rates of violent crime.

headline.print_headline: Wielding Paintbrushes, Not Spray Cans, at a Housing Project
headline.main: Wielding Paintbrushes, Not Spray Cans, at Bronx Housing Project

snippet: A mural program called Public Art/Public Housing is being conducted in five New York City low-income housing projects with high rates of violent crime.
abstract: New York City-financed Public Art/Public Housing project has paired Housing Authority with community arts group Groundswell to create murals at five low income housing developments in city with high rates of violent crime; funding for project, which recruits residents aged 16 to 24, was initiated by City Councilman Richie Torres, who sees effort as way to allow young residents of public housing to tell rich and complex stories of their lives through art.
